He currently works at the Bosch Home Comfort Group as a Refrigeration Engineer for Heat Pumps Development, particularly of R290 Air-to-Water systems, with a focus on the development and use of Dymola/Modelica models to run simulations of both individual components and of the complete system He is also involved in cooperation projects with the local University, both in terms of research and of student MSc thesis/internship supervision.

profile_positions.description: I currently work at the Bosch Home Comfort Group as a Refrigeration Engineer for Heat Pumps Development, particularly of R290 Air-to-Water systems. I am part of the HC-ES/PAB-E2 team, namely in the calculation/simulation group. I focus on the development and use of Dymola/Modelica models to run simulations of both individual components (heat exchangers, valves, compressors, …) and of the complete system, in addition to the use of Matlab and other specialized software to perform a variety of ancillary tasks. I am also involved in cooperation projects with the local University, both in terms of research and of student MSc thesis/internship supervision.
profile_positions.title: Senior Mechanical Development Engineer

profile_positions.description:
My tasks at the Joint Research Centre have more recently involved the support to the European Commission in general  - the Directorate-General for Energy in particular - regarding the ongoing crisis, namely by analysing and reviewing Member States’ Emergency and Preventive Action Plans, and collecting and analysing gas flow information for the purpose of establishing possible responses.

I was also actively involved in defining evaluation methodologies for the 6th list of Projects of Common Interest, in the thematic areas of Hydrogen and Carbon Dioxide Transport Networks. Regarding the latter, I also evaluated applications in the 4th and 5th lists.

I have also reviewed national and regional gas transmission system Risk Assessments, and supported some Member States in the elaboration of their national RAs, namely in the estimation of risk scenario consequences using hydraulic simulations. In addition, I have assessed technology needs, possible bottlenecks and other related problems in the LNG sector.

I have conducted hydraulic simulations of EU Gas Transmission Networks, including interactions with Electricity Transmission Networks and ICT/SCADA systems. Results fed into various work packages contributing to increase awareness of the risk the EU energy networks are faced with. This work required a close cooperation with the Member States concerned and their Transmission System Operators, as well as partners in industry, academia, DG HOME and DG ENER.

I have contributed to the EC’s and the Member States’ Energy Critical Infrastructures Protection efforts, within the framework of European Programme for Critical Infrastructure Protection (EPCIP) and the Gas Security of Supply Regulation (994/2010) and Regulation (EU) 2017/1938 concerning measures to safeguard the security of gas supply by developing methodologies to identify the most relevant EU Gas Transmission Network risks and vulnerabilities.
profile_positions.title: Scientific Project Officer (Contract Agent Grade 16)

profile_positions.description:
My tasks as a Grantholder at the JRC's Energy Security, Systems and Market Unit were part of the framework where studies to identify the key vulnerabilities of the European Gas Transmission Network are carried out, in order to determine needs and actions to make it less vulnerable and contribute to increase the level of Security of Gas Supply in the EU.

For this purpose I have co-developed a methodology to identify the most relevant EU Gas Transmission Network vulnerabilities. I have run hydraulic simulations of the European Gas Transmission Network (at the national and regional levels, with 2 or 3 Member States) together with facility failure mode models to conduct a Vulnerability Analysis in order to simulate relevant scenarios in order to identify key network shortcomings.
profile_positions.title: Scientific Project Officer (Grantholder Grade 30)

profile_positions.description:
The research presented in my Doctoral thesis was funded by FCT (Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia - Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology) through the SFRH / BD / 25352 / 2005 PhD grant, with the title “Transient Transpiration Radiometer – Development of a Heat Flux Sensor for High Aggressivity Environments”. 

A new instrument for the measurement of convective and radiative heat transfer components was proposed and developed, based on the transient operation of a transpiration radiometer. Previous transpiration radiometers relied on steady state temperature measurements in a porous element crossed by a known gas mass flow. As a consequence of the porous sensing element’s intrinsically high thermal inertia, the instrument’s time constant was in the order of several seconds. 

The proposed instrument preserved established advantages of transpiration radiometers while incorporating additional features that broaden their applicability range. The most important developments were a significant reduction of the instrument’s response time and the possibility of separating and measuring the convective and radiative components of the heat flux. These objectives are achieved through the analysis of the instrument’s transient response, a pulsed gas flow being used to induce the transient behaviour. A thin microperforated steel plate was used instead of the earlier, thicker sinterized steel sensing element.

A thorough literature review was followed by the development of two distinct analytical models (based on Green’s Functions and Finite Differences) and the comparison of their results with those obtained using commercial Computational Fluids Dynamics software. Dimensioning procedures were discussed and applied to the design of prototypes, which were then built, tested and calibrated.

Patent PT106475 was also granted as a result of the work developed in this framework.
profile_positions.title: Doctoral research student

profile_positions.description:
The GALP 20-20-20 Protocol was a training programme funded by GALP, which is the main petroleum company and one of the larger utilities and energy services companies in Portugal. The University of Aveiro selected the candidate trainees and provided advice during the course of the programme.

Within the framework of this protocol, trainees were allocated to companies in a diversity of industrial sectors but in all cases with large energy consumptions. The trainees’ main assignment was to come up with cost-effective energy consumption optimization strategies and measures.

My functions included providing technical advice to the trainees regarding the evaluation of the various methodologies to be implemented and helping them use effectively specific software, namely Computational Fluid Dynamics (ANSYS CFX) and Energy Efficiency (RetScreen) applications, and also to evaluate their performance together with their supervisors in each company.

The companies where my trainees were assigned ranged from large iron (Funfrap) and glass (BA Vidros) foundries to similarly large paper mills (Celbi), as well as ceramic tiles (Revigrés) and porcelain (Vista Alegre) factories, heating equipment (Bosch Termotecnologia) and cork- (Amorim Revestimentos and CAI – Corticeira Amorim Indústria) and wood-based (Sonae Indústria – Produção e Comercialização de Derivados de Madeira) products manufacturers, as well as animal feed producers (Progado).

I am glad to say that several of my trainees were awarded some of the annual prizes for best traineeship work.
profile_positions.title: Tutor/Consultant – GALP-University of Aveiro Protocol

profile_positions.description:
The research was funded by FCT ( Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia - Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology) through the POCTI/EME/41349/01 grant, with the title “Diagnostic System for Thermal Applications”, and was the basis of my MSc dissertation.

Proper diagnostic and monitoring systems are essential in industrial hardware, considering purchase and operation costs. Increases in availability and reliability are highly desirable, being especially relevant regarding thermal equipment, namely in terms of energy consumption costs.

I used CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics) tools to build a "virtual" furnace, validated with experimental data. This model was used to simulate both normal and “faulty” behaviours, regarding parameters such as energy conversion efficiency, steam leakage and fouling. A database was developed comprising normal situations and simulated fault sets, characterized by virtual sensor outputs used in the evaluation of diagnostic parameters patterns to be processed and recognized by the diagnostic system.

The database was processed using ANN (Artificial Neural Networks), with satisfactory results even in their most simple form trained using standard algorithms. Pattern recognition was thus performed, identifying root causes of simulated anomalies.

The Valor Humano programme was promoted by the Minho Region (North-western Portugal) Industrial Association in order to promote energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures across its associated companies.

Within this framework I provided a variety of consultancy services for particular technical matters, including technical analysis, design and dimensioning calculations and numerical simulations of relevant processes and machinery, as well as financial analysis of measures to be implemented. I also provided teaching/training sessions to the staff of the companies involved.
